sentence: Editor’s note: InvestorPlace’s Earnings Reports to Watch is updated weekly.
Please check back next week for our latest .
A quiet earnings slate next week still is worth watching.
There aren’t likely to be any earnings reports that, on their own, can move the overall market.
But as often has been the case of late, there are more than a few that could signal where the overall market might be headed.
Right now, the market seems a bit nervous.
The S&P 500 touched a two-month low on Thursday.
still dominates the headlines.

And while earnings season overall was strong, there were a few significant misses — 3M (NYSE:) and Alphabet (NASDAQ:, NASDAQ:GOOGL) among them — that hit major indices and highlighted worries in key sectors.
Two more struggling sectors will see key earnings reports next week.
And a tech bellwether that historically has reflected broader market sentiment has an important release of its own.
Investors may not follow next week’s earnings calendar all that closely, given the lack of big stocks and the continuing focus on external worries.
But savvy investors should.
Ahead of fourth-quarter earnings from Salesforce.com (NYSE:) in March, I wrote that the reaction to earnings might well signal in which direction tech was headed.
That prediction played out to some extent.
CRM stock did , but it regained those losses relatively quickly.
Since then, Salesforce, much like the market as a whole, has traded mostly sideways before a recent dip.
Correlation doesn’t necessarily mean causation, but CRM earnings on Tuesday afternoon could again give a clue as to investor sentiment.
There’s really no argument about the value and quality of the Salesforce.com business model — the .
If investors sell off a strong report from Salesforce.com — and history suggests the company will again beat Street estimates — that could be a sign that valuation concerns have returned.
Confirmation could come from another software high-flyer, MongoDB (NASDAQ:), which reports on Wednesday afternoon.
Sell-offs in both stocks could mean valuations have hit a ceiling.
And in a market still near all-time highs, that would not be good news.
The retail sector — and mall retailers in particular — desperately needs a good report from American Eagle Outfitters (NYSE:).
Earnings reports across the industry have been something close to disastrous.
Fellow teen retailer Abercrombie & Fitch (NYSE:) plunged after its earnings this week.
Tilly’s (NYSE:) dropped 18%.
Mall stalwart Gap (NYSE:) is down double-digits.
Michael Kors owner Capri Holdings (NYSE:) fell 10%.
Department stores haven’t been immune, either, with Nordstrom (NYSE:) and Kohl’s (NYSE:) both declining sharply after their own reports.
Investors seem to believe American Eagle is next: AEO shares have fallen by more than 26% in the past month.
Another poor report from another mall leader likely puts the entire sector in the penalty box.
Any sign of life from American Eagle, however, might tempt some investors to time the bottom not just in AEO, but in its fellow mall plays.
There are similarities between CPG (consumer packaged goods) plays like Campbell Soup (NYSE:) and retailers like AEO.
Both sectors took a big hit last year, particularly in the end-of-year sell-off.
Secular changes like more competition from startups and margin pressure from end consumers’ focus on pricing have pressured both industries.
And both sectors rallied at the beginning of this year.
The rally in retail is falling apart; CPG plays might be next.
CPB, after touching a six-year low in December, at one point was up 20% in 2019.
It has pulled back, however, dropping 8% in just two weeks.
And it’s likely sector weakness is at play, perhaps driven by tariff concerns.
Industry leader Kraft Heinz (NASDAQ:) continues to fall, touching a new low on Thursday.

A good report from Campbell Soup isn’t likely to reverse those pressures – but it could drive at least some confidence that branded products manufacturers have a path forward amid pressures on both costs and revenue.
A disappointing report, however, especially with few earnings reports in the sector on the horizon until late July, will only add to the narrative that the entire industry is headed for trouble.
And that could lead CPG stock to follow retailers for the second time in 2019 — only this time, in the wrong direction.
As of this writing, Vince Martin is long shares of Gap Inc.
He has no positions in any securities mentioned.
The post appeared first on InvestorPlace.
